body.p: Organization of higher education in Lexington, Kentucky. Established by an act of the assembly of the Commonwealth of Virginia as Transylvania Seminary in 1780. First classes held in Danville in 1785. Earliest religious affiliations were with the Episcopal and Presbyterian churches. Campus moved to Lexington, Kentucky, in 1789. Transylvania University, including a law school, medical school, divinity school, and college of arts and sciences, was established by the legislature of the Commonwealth of Kentucky on January 1, 1799. Affiliated with the Methodist Church from 1841 to 1865. Transylvania University merged with Kentucky University and lost its name from 1865 to 1908. While part of Kentucky University, it affiliated with the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) beginning in 1865. Kentucky University split, with portions of the university reclaiming the name of Transylvania University, in 1908.
